Can I just say, if this is how things were presented in school, how many more kids would actually be EXCITED about science. And chemistry. And physics. And math.

My brain is the kind that doesn't really like logic all that much, so subjects like math for example have always been a struggle. There isn't anything creative in it, it an exact science, i can't add anything from my own self like i could if I was writing an essay. The way that it was presented as well was dry and just not interesting at all.

I am now falling in love with it. All the things I once thought were so difficult and boring are now literally blowing my mind, I stand so humbled before them. This is what I've been missing, this channel. It sparked my physics curiosity by taking away the intimidating factor. And I am just so so grateful. Now my brain is like "More. MORE. I just need everyone to realize it's completely insane to think firing a rocket into a black hole would do literally anything.  Also, it doesn't have to be a "ringularity" whatever tf that even means.  Singularities are infinitely dense points, not magically round halos that make no physical sense.  The star that they came from was a ball that rotates, the singularity is an infinitely small ball that rotates.  Yes, I know it isn't that simple, but this video is one massive cringe sessions of things that make no sense if you consider actual realty and how black holes form and how they pull matter in and act.  How does it make sense to be able to build a material civilization near the singularity of a black hole?  Why is one of the most gravity dense places in the Universe a place you think you can exist as an organic life form?  Also, the 12-inch-thick mirror scenario around a black hole is so bad it doesn't even deserve to be ripped apart.  Too much theoretical, not enough physics.   This was so painful to listen to.

So long as fundamentals of science is not related to satisfaction of needs of beings, all these explanations and predictions through much glorified inquisity, imaginations and speculations is sheer waste of time and would only pave the way for more disasters .

The problem of war as well as other disastors human race faces has a far deeper cause than everybody believes.

It is rooted in the fundamentals of what all on this earth believe to be the means for acquiring knowledge:

EXPERIMENTAL AND OBSERVATIONAL SCIENCE WITHOUT ANY CLEARLY STATED PURPOSE.

This is comparable with going to a supermarket and analyzing everything available in it to find out what to buy. One must know what one needs before going to the supermarket. Otherwise one would buy all kinds of rubbish promoted by the seller.

That is exactly what our glorified experimental and observational science does at present: developing all kinds of nonliving tools without any idea about how LIFE develops.

There is no mathematical formula describing how a seed is composed from soil. The whole of glorified CALCULUS is useless when it comes to analyzing development of seeds from nonliving matter or growth of plants from them. Yet that is the only thing on which all life (including all carnivoures) depends every single day. Nobody even notices this absence (defect) in the fundamentals of science, glorified by everybody.

We must search for knowledge only to satisfy our own needs. This can only happen if we quantize our needs particle physically and link their satisfaction to plants by equally quantizing NUMBERS and interpreting the four elementary arithmetic operations as interactions among those quantized particles.

As weapons manufacture would be a fundamentally prohibited function in such a system and all knowledge must link to sustenance of PLANTS and ANIMALS eternally there can be no disasters or wars in that system.

This would require substituting the
general relativistic formula of the universe:

Spacetime curvature = matter and energy

with the particle physical formula of life function:

Needs = means of their satisfaction
= growth of and on plants

Until this is done we'd continue to waste our time analyzing one man made problem after another eternally, while natural disastors pile up on the other side and the greatist scientists fiddle analyzing the cuses of Big Bang, Dark Matter, Dark Energy, Black Holes,..... And the richest of them design machines to reach the stars and explore the universe; similar to the father, who wastes all what he earns in drinks and gambling while own children starve.

this reminds me of a VERY old science book i have, "black holes and warped spacetime", which theorized that a spinning black hole would have TWO event horizons, and the area in between would effectively reverse space and time...so it could be used as a time machine, or a portal into a different dimension...
it ALSO said that something passing through the center of a "ringularity" might wind up in a dimension where GRAVITY IS REVERSED! WEIRD!

i also read a sci-fi novel called "the doomsday effect", about trying to catch a tiny black hole that is orbiting around and partly through earth, before it destroys earth.
near the end, someone thinks they could reverse a black hole and turn it into a "white hole", that constantly spits out matter and energy until it fades completely, by dropping a large quantity of Antimatter into it!

A black hole is a region of spacetime where gravity is so strong that nothing—no particles or even electromagnetic radiation such as light —can escape from it. The theory of general relativity predicts that a sufficiently compact mass can deform spacetime.
(Grades K-4) series. A black hole is a place in space where gravity pulls so much that even light can not get out. The gravity is so strong because matter has been squeezed into a tiny space. This can happen when a star is dying.
This article is part of the NASA Knows! (Grades K-4) series. A black hole is a place in space where gravity pulls so much that even light can not get out. The gravity is so strong because matter has been squeezed into a tiny space. This can happen when a star is dying. Because no light can get out, people can't see black holes.

Technically speaking, there is no such thing as a singularity, because infinite density is impossible due to quantum mechanics.  The presence of singularities in the math in relativity just indicates that relativity is incomplete, and can't describe what happens inside the event horizon.  So in reality, we don't know what's INSIDE the black hole.  But all the stuff we do to interact with the black hole from outside the event horizon still works as described here.

The Penrose process is feasible (and it's similar but not the same to what spacecraft already use to harness the gravitational and rotational energy from planets and gain an energy boost), but the issue with creating a black hole mirror is that you'd need to find a black hole which is relatively isolated. Black holes generally attract stuff around them which gets sucked into them, and so any mirror which one sets into place around a black hole is likely to get destroyed by stuff trying to enter the black hole, especially given how long it would likely take to set up such a mirror. Even more concerning is the unimaginable amount of resources required to create that mirror.

At the same time, we can hope that, in the far, far future, there might be some way to address these more pragmatic concerns.

The thing I don't get with this - or with Dyson Spheres - is how exactly you would set such a thing up.  Like that's always glossed over.  But take the whole "Dyson Sphere around Sol" idea.  Ignoring the part where eliminating solar winds leaves us open to horrific amounts of cosmic radiation, the sun is travelling really, really fast, dragging the planets in its wake.  And that seems key to me; we're always trailing in the wake of the sun.  How do you get in front of the sun?  And then, if you do manage to like, use a slingshot maneuver to get ahead of the sun, how do you slow it down to match the sun's velocity as it circles the galaxy's center?  Once you pass the sun, you need your Dyson Sphere bits to match speed so that they can stay positioned in front instead of speeding off where you can't attach them to the rest of the sphere.  Same thing applies to a black hole, which would also be moving at absurd rates of speed  Setting up this giant mirror outside the ergosphere would involve assembling pieces around an object that's hurtling through space at hundreds of thousands of miles per hour and pissing out lethal radiation and oh, by the way, you need to get this all assembled before the pieces spiral into the event horizon, so the clock is ticking.  Not to mention, a 10cm thick sphere around a galactic supermassive black hole... I don't even know how much matter that would take (suppose it depends entirely on the radius of the sphere), but that has to be like whole ass star systems worth of mass, and not in abundant elements like H or He, but in metals, and I have to imagine that it's important that your reflectivity is pretty consistent throughout, so you can't just use whatever metals you can find laying about.  And then if that mirrored sphere is impacted by large space debris, or shot through by a primordial black hole (which seems far more likely than the low probability of one passing through the Earth, given that the mirror would be many, many times larger than our little green-and-blue speck).  I realize that I am as layman as layman gets, but the technological challenges that would need to be overcome seem unsurmountable to me.

Black holes: massive stuff in space that suck everything inside and never let anything out. What's inside of it is unknown, but we can only define it as a singularity that contains whatever the black hole has sucked in.

1. How can we harvest energy from moving energy?

2. If the Ergosphere is spinning, and the blackhole is sucking, but the Ergosphere is preventing the sucking, doesn't this mean that the Ergosphere has an extreme kinetic force, which is probably higher than the speed of light, that it can stop black holes from sucking stuff in? Wouldn't it be too dangerous to try and use such high kinetic force to power Earth? Isn't just one beam of the speedy energy enough to power the whole planet? And, if the Ergosphere has enough kinetic force to top the black hole from sucking items in, then how can we take items out of the Ergosphere?

3. Black holes bend space-time. Ergospheres can do "half" of the bending a black hole can manage to do. Even so, wouldn't it mean that if we send in energy at the start of a year, it would come back to us at the end of the same year? Isn't there a chance that it won't come back to be used, be to destroy??

That's all. If you can answer these question for me, then I would really appreciate that, as I hope to learn as much as possible about these kinds of stuff.

There's a reason the mirror won't work, and neither any kind dyson sphere for that matter. It's actually impossible! I'm an engineer. Let me explain.

If the dyson sphere stood still it would be an unstable configuration and fall into the black hole on the side where it was closest to the black hole. You can't change the position of the black hole since it's so much larger, so you will need to constantly move the dyson sphere in order to keep it from falling into the black hole on one side. The amount of energy required to push the dyson sphere away from the black hole is ludicrous and probably more than you will receive from the power generation.

If you want the dyson sphere somewhat stable and keep it from falling into the black hole, you can try to make the dyson sphere spin with an rotational velocity high enough to make it orbit the black hole. Once it's in orbit, you won't need to constantly keep it up. However, if you want keep the dyson sphere close to the black hole, then it will be so close that the orbital velocity becomes close to the speed of light, so you will need an ludicrous amount of energy to spin it that fast in the first place.

Even worse, the dyson sphere would still be unstable at its poles since the parts one poles aren't spinning around a legal orbit. This means that they would have a natural tendency to fall into the black hole. To keep the poles from falling down, you will need to keep them upright by structurally supporting them by letting the orbital equator of the dyson sphere take the load "sideways"; like a bridge, only around and over the pole. However, this bridge will need to be strong enough to support 16 million tons of downwards pull on each square centimeter (given that you orbit close to a small black hole). There is no material which is strong enough to support it! So, every part of the dyson sphere which is not perfectly aligned with the equator will be spagettified and fall down into the black hole.

The only way to combat this spaghettification is to build a large dyson sphere reaching far away outside of the black hole. However, the net pull on the entire structure would still be the same, so it would still require a ludicrous amount of structural material to support it - as well as already being big in the first place. In that case you will need even more material, and even more energy to spin it, and so on.

Furthermore, when the sphere becomes this big, it will lose its purpose! When a light photon hits a mirror, some of its energy gets absorbed, say 5% or so. If the dyson sphere becomes big enough, I believe the black hole in the center will be so small compared to the total volume that almost no light rays will hit the black hole - making the whole power plant lose more energy than it gains due to more frequent mirror absorption events than black hole boost events.

In conclusion, not possible unless we discover some kind of sci-fi exotic strong material to withstand spaghettification or a perfect mirror which absorbes 0% light when reflecting.

1:50 you really ought to explain something core to the universe here..
Instead of saying "spinning black holes are special" or "like with non-spinning black holes..."
Because there are NO black holes in the real universe that are non-spinning.
They ALL spin. EVERYTHING spins in the universe. There is nothing that doesnt spin, period.

So its kind of giving the wrong impression when you talk about spinning black holes as being something special, when in fact, its the ONLY kind that exists. Yes, its mostly a flaw with theoretical (and applied) physics in our society, that they do calculations and science on stationary black holes, because its easier to calculate, and then write textbooks based on those formulas.
While in actual non-math-human-invented space, EVERYTHING is spinning.

So all those textbooks describing static black holes, are in fact wrong.
Because everything spins. There is no shortcut to take, you cannot just calculate as if it was not spinning, because the spin itself massively changes how objects, gravity, time, and space itself behaves.

This is one problem of our mainstream established academic science.
We're so focused on our own human-invented theories and mind gymnastics, that we're forgetting that we're meant to describe the ACTUAL universe and how it works, not a simplified non-existing version.

It's like if you were writing a medical textbook about how the heart works as a static unmoving object, without factoring in or mentioning that it moves, and beats.
It's entirely wrong, and your conclusions will be entirely wrong too. It works in our minds to imagine mathematics, but it doesnt represent reality.

We know little about black holes because they are distant, and have never been closely observed.  We could never orbit a craft even remotely near one, outside the 'event horizon', so using them would be a wistful dream.  Even a tiny one would be so dense as to be unsupportable by our materials and unmovable too.  Magnetic containment might be applicable, but even then the demands would be enormous and the 'target' of such an attack would have a lot of warning...

Based on General Relativity, time and gravity don’t really exist how we see them, visualize earth sitting on its little cut of space in its existence, in quantum mechanics, this mass will have a pull, resulting in things like the moon rotating around it, but Einstein challenged this and in many ways won. Earth still sits on its chunk of space, but instead of it having a pull, its mass distorts space, resulting in a bend in space and space around it rotating, of course this would be the orbiting of the moon, due to the distortion, it parallels to the absorption of light, light take roughly 8 minutes to travel to earth, this is because of how earth affects space, for light, it is constantly time traveling, it doesn’t matter if it’s 8 minutes or 8 billion years for it to travel to a mass, it feels the same to light because it can’t accelerate or slow its self down due to the weightlessness of its photons. When the distortion happens, the perception we call time is most definitely affected, “time” is much slower the further away from the center of the distortion you go, look into the twin theory for proof. The way I see it, the only way we can divide pass present and future is the measurement of light, and the perception of change to realize what happened yesterday and last year. He forgot one very important phenomenon: Hawking Radiation. A black hole actually does slowly lose mass over time. The physics of this are complicated, but it has to do with the curvature of the event horizon, so the smaller the black hole, the more energy it radiates. So for example if you could somehow find a way to create a black hole with about the mass of Mt Everest, it would be extremely tiny, but emit a tremendous amount of radiation.

For other uses, see Event horizon (disambiguation) and Horizon (general relativity).
Part of a series of articles about
General relativity
Spacetime curvature schematic
IntroductionHistory
Mathematical formulation
Tests

In astrophysics, an event horizon is a boundary beyond which events cannot affect an observer. The term was coined by Wolfgang Rindler.[1]

In 1784, John Michell proposed that near compact massive objects, gravity can be strong enough that even light cannot escape. At that time, the Newtonian theory of gravitation and the so-called corpuscular theory of light were dominant. In these theories, if the escape speed of an object exceeds the speed of light, then light originating inside or from it can escape temporarily but will return. In 1958, David Finkelstein used General Relativity to introduce a stricter definition of a local black hole event horizon as a boundary beyond which events of any kind cannot affect an outside observer. This led to information and firewall paradoxes, which encouraged the re-examination of the concept of local event horizons and the notion of black holes. Several theories were subsequently developed, some with and some without event horizons. Stephen Hawking, who was one of the leading developers of theories to describe black holes, suggested that an apparent horizon should be used instead of an event horizon, saying "gravitational collapse produces apparent horizons but no event horizons". He eventually concluded that "the absence of event horizons mean that there are no black holes – in the sense of regimes from which light can't escape to infinity."[2][3] This does not mean denying the existence of black holes, it merely expresses the distrust towards the conventional strict definition of the event horizon.
Any object that approaches the horizon from the observer's side appears to slow down and never quite crosses the horizon.[4] Due to gravitational redshift, its image reddens over time as the object moves away from the observer.[5]
In an expanding universe the speed of expansion reaches and even exceeds the speed of light, which prevents signals from travelling to some regions. A cosmic event horizon is a real event horizon because it affects all kinds of signals, including gravitational waves which travel at the speed of light.

Why not go into a younger universe, to escape extinction? By the way, Marx’s black hole attack would have an mass of 11.455 times that of the Earth. It’d last 2.69*10^61 seconds (black holes are like the Highlanders of the cosmos), so Hawking radiation is negligible. But the gravity definitely ain’t. If Marx created a black hole on our moon, it’d tear the moon apart, and we’d begin to orbit it instead. Best-case, tidal forces completely change the way the Earth rotates, and thus gets light from the Sun, as well as suffers being stretched into a egg-shape. Worst-case, Earth too falls into the black hole. For the neighboring planets, their orbits would be disrupted a bit.

Actually it's a bit more complicated and you said some things wrong. You are talking about a KERR type black whole which is the most common in universe (actually the only one certain to be existing) but the Swarzchild type of black whole is still theorically possible. And in that type of black whole, the singularity is not a point in space it's a moment in time. When you enter a black whole you can imagine (although is not exactly like that) that the space-time has bended so much that space is now time and time is now space. That makes that the event horizon you just crossed is no longer behind you, instead is in your past and the singularity is not in front of you, it's in your future. If you wanted to search for that singularity point in space, you wouldn't find it anywhere because it's nowhere, it's in your future. Similar things happen to the KERR type (the one you are talking about) it's true that there is a ringularity that is actually somewhere in space in this type of black whole, but that ringularity is surrounded by something called the "Cauchy horizon" that is a barrier in which classical physics just can't handle it anymore. But that Cauchy horizon is really really unstable, it's like trying to keep a pencil verticalin a table only by equilibrium of his top...any small interference will make it fall. Same applies to that Cauchy horizon, something interacting with the black whole will make it fall, you playing around in the ergosphere is more than enough to do that. Once that Cauchy horizon is fallen, the ringularity stops being a ring in a place and comes back to being a moment in time. So in practical situations, if you want to go find that ringularity, you won't, the simple act of you falling into the black whole will make that ringularity "dissapear" from where it is and it will become a moment in your future.

Seems like this could be the gateway to faster-than-light travel. Only black holes can exceed the speed of light, so perhaps harnessing their energy could lead to technology capable of warping space and time, allowing matter to essentially teleport. This would change our perspective of the universe forever, as looking through telescopes would no longer be the primary method of gathering information about outer space. After all, if we can send ourselves countless light-years away, we'd absolutely be able to do the same with light, sound, and every other form of transmittable information. Distance would be rendered obsolete. No doubt, whatever miracle energy we gather from black holes would be the most covetted resource in the universe, akin to oil today. After all, it would be mandatory to allow interstellar travel AND communication. Without it, people would be completely stranded.

The best part is that space exploration is notoriously cheap for how much potential it has to propel mankind into the future. If the nations of the world would just put their differences aside, and work towards building a better future, we would be so much better off as a species.

the problem with a black holes angular momentum is that it doesnt create an entropic difference in a local reference frame. Yes you could put something into its orbit, but it isnt actually the object that attains any momentum, it just stands still as the space around it moves around the black hole, any object trying to utilize this momentum would also move with the same momentum and there is no entropy gradient to use.

the most applicable way to use a black hole as energy source is to create one as a form of battery, by preventing as much energy loss due to hawking radiation as possible, while keeping it microscopic. Due to hawking radiation, small black holes emit enormous amounts of thermal radiation that can be harnessed, and it depends on the mass of the black hole.

by feeding the black hole "stuff" in some form or manner, you can convert anything you toss into it to thermal radiation with 100% efficiency. Its basically a matter-energy converter.
key issue here is containing the energy output of a microscopic black hole and somehow being able to also drop matter into it consistently to prevent the microscopic black hole from shrinking too fast and in essence turning into the largest bomb you could possible build.

once you leave the ergosphere your speed relative to the black hole would decrease as you leave the space that is whirling around it unless you remove part of your space ship to drop into the black hole, a process you cant do with photons for energy creation. Additionaly, the angular momentum decreases everytime you do this and will reduce the amount of energy you could potentially gain with the penrose trade, it will at some point cease, transforming it into a non rotating black hole and making it impossible to gain any energy this way. Worth noting for the idea of bouncing light in a mirror is that this too drains angular momentum (if it were possible) and light would follow an arced curve along spacetime. It is impossible to make light bounce in curved space without eventually falling into the black hole itself, losing all the "potential" energy gained.

If you think about it, it becomes immediatly clear why this wont work. You need perfekt mirrors! We humas can only see a certain range of photons and when all of them are reflekted whe call it a mirror. If not everything is reflected, you can destroy it with a simple powerful laser. So first off the mirror would need to be kept cool in some way. Second and more importantly, you may have heard that short wavelength radiation can not be stopped, neither can it be mirrored. More and more energy means just, shorter and shorter wavelength and so that mirror would get to an equilibrium where it would just convert the black hole into a gamma radiator. But we already have enough of those in the universe. It would definitely not turn a black hole into a bomb.

the heat death of the universe is a hypothesis with very little evidence. It is equally possible that galaxies and stars recycle themselves endlessly and that the actual age of the universe is a trillion trillion trillion trillion years rather than the paltry 13 billion years they estimate. It does this through constantly recycling matter into light and light back into matter. Matter slowly leaks away as EM radiation, and at the same time EM radiation is recycled into matter and energizes it. The end result is that the net total of energy neither increases nor decreases.

Photons released as matter decays don't just radiate away blindly in every direction, never to be seen again. Instead, it flows in magnetic channels, travelling along giant galactic magnetic field lines and entering into the magnetic poles of charged matter. So the light that is emitted out of stars and the light that matter decays into as it dies doesn't just go off into the distance in a straight line but rather loops back into the creation of new matter.

Even if all the matter in the universe became pure photons, collisions between x-ray and gamma ray photons would once again create electrons and protons, which would be snapped together by photon charge channeling, and creating new magnetic fields which would draw in more photons to create more protons and electrons and eventually gravity would form new stars. But there's no reason to assume that all matter will die at the same time because it wasn't created at the same time -- instead, the universe is dying, and being reformed and recycled as we speak. Its in a constant state of disintegration and becoming, simultaneously. It never ends and it never begins. It just is.

No "point" singularities exist. Their definition doesn't even make physical sense.  No surface area, no dimensions in X, Y, or Z, and "infinitely small" means it doesn't physically exist.  Blackholes need to ditch the singularity math and just be dark stars again. They're like neutron stars, very dense, but they're spheres with 3 dimensions,  but their density crosses a certain threshold  that forms a crystalline structure that blocks the re-emission of photons.  So it's a neutron star that doesn't give off light because the particles are organized in such a way that there's no "holes" for photons to flow through. In a literal sense, black holes are the least "hole" of all matter. A regular atom is full of holes, like a donut, with photons flowing through the holes. But a black hole is composed of donuts with their holes stuffed and blocked so charge and light can't flow through it, any incoming photons is immediately redirected to the poles and emitted through the jet streams.

While the black hole bomb has a theoretically absurd yield in a perfect physical simulation, its practical yield would be limited to something quite tiny by the structure of your mirror. Basically the mirror's efficiency (or lack thereof - nothing is 100% efficient), means that a small proportion of the EM wave's energy will be absorbed by the mirror with each bounce, becoming heat energy in the mirror.
In practice your mirror will simply melt, or perhaps even explosively vaporize if the rate of transfer is sufficiently fast - but this will happen LONG before you've extracted a meaningful amount of energy from the black hole itself, once the mirror loses structural integrity, the process stops. Ultimately you can't really extract more energy from the black hole bomb this way than it takes to destroy the mirror itself, which isn't much at all.
It's like making a bomb using a rigid canister containing slow burning black powder - the explosive force of the bomb really doesn't get any better than the rupture strength of the canister, regardless of how much black powder you put in it.
On the other hand, if you are extracting usable energy from the black hole, you can keep that up as long as you keep your mirrors cool enough to keep them from losing integrity, so it does still work fine as a power source - but not a bomb.

The REALLY weird thing is, that in the ergosphere of a black hole, gravity is stronger sideways than it is down. You can resist falling in, but not being spun around. Imagine if gravity on Earth went from West to East with 2 g's of acceleration, in addition to 1 g of acceleration down. It's like that. But this doesn't actually let you get the core mass of a black hole for fuel, only the portion of its energy taken by its rotation. And once you use it, you can't use any more of the black hole's mass.

so... I had a „showerthought“...
The singularity is ... basically a zero dimensional thing... meaning that we ... theoretically have a way to another dimension. you don‘t go anywhere, you stay in that point. Going by the Einstein-Rosen bridge theory: If white holes are real, and we find one, then... we could go into one and get to another dimension, like the 4th or 5th space dimension. getting there would be like looking at a point that IS our universe... which could be saying that you can go to parallel universes by either going over the border of our universe OR into a white hole... though... then there‘d be an abundance of white holes. My solution or explanation: white holes have a lifetime of a planck second... or how it‘s called. an infinitely short moment, that translates to a very long time on a lower dimension. just like our black holes, they are the thing that lives the longest in our / their universe, working as a one way gate to a higher dimension. I doubt we can steal any energy caused by increasing speed (because of "rotation"). This is not a speed, this is just space-time which is curved, so there is no any speed gain, it's the time what increases for you when you are close to the event horizon. So when you leave the black hole, thinking you have stolen something, you will have nothing when you arrive back to the normal space-time (not curved). So you can't use the black hole as a sort of engine boost, there is no speed boost, just the time goes faster there, so once you left - everything is back to normal.

A black hole is a region of spacetimeexhibiting such strong gravitational effects that nothing—not even particles and electromagnetic radiation such as light—can escape from inside it.[6] The theory of general relativity predicts that a sufficiently compact mass can deform spacetime to form a black hole.[7][8] The boundary of the region from which no escape is possible is called the event horizon. Although the event horizon has an enormous effect on the fate and circumstances of an object crossing it, no locally detectable features appear to be observed.[9] In many ways, a black hole acts like an ideal black body, as it reflects no light.[10][11] Moreover, quantum field theory in curved spacetime predicts that event horizons emit Hawking radiation, with the same spectrum as a black body of a temperature inversely proportional to its mass. This temperature is on the order of billionths of a kelvin for black holes of stellar mass, making it essentially impossible to observe.

Objects whose gravitational fields are too strong for light to escape were first considered in the 18th century by John Michell and Pierre-Simon Laplace.[12] The first modern solution of general relativity that would characterize a black hole was found by Karl Schwarzschild in 1916, although its interpretation as a region of space from which nothing can escape was first published by David Finkelstein in 1958. Black holes were long considered a mathematical curiosity; it was during the 1960s that theoretical work showed they were a generic prediction of general relativity. The discovery of neutron stars by Jocelyn Bell Burnell in 1967 sparked interest in gravitationally collapsed compact objects as a possible astrophysical reality.

Black holes of stellar mass are expected to form when very massive stars collapse at the end of their life cycle. After a black hole has formed, it can continue to grow by absorbing mass from its surroundings. By absorbing other stars and merging with other black holes, supermassive black holes of millions of solar masses (M☉) may form. There is general consensus that supermassive black holes exist in the centers of most galaxies.

Despite its invisible interior, the presence of a black hole can be inferred through its interaction with other matter and with electromagnetic radiation such as visible light. Matter that falls onto a black hole can form an external accretion disk heated by friction, forming some of the brightest objects in the universe. If there are other stars orbiting a black hole, their orbits can be used to determine the black hole's mass and location. Such observations can be used to exclude possible alternatives such as neutron stars. In this way, astronomers have identified numerous stellar black hole candidates in binary systems, and established that the radio source known as Sagittarius A*, at the core of the Milky Way galaxy, contains a supermassive black hole of about 4.3 million solar masses.

On 11 February 2016, the LIGO collaboration announced the first direct detection of gravitational waves, which also represented the first observation of a black hole merger.[13]As of December 2018, eleven gravitational wave events have been observed that originated from ten merging black holes (along with one binary neutron star merger).[14][15] On 10 April 2019, the first ever direct image of a black hole and its vicinity was published, following observations made by the Event Horizon Telescope in 2017 of the supermassive black hole in Messier 87's galactic centre.

The black hole bomb sounds plausible, but it doesn't seem the case with some analysis. Problems from this idea arises from these reasons: 1) Mirrors don't reflect all light, some portion is absorbed. 2) Mirrors don't reflect all wavelengths equally. The materials we use for mirrors reflect the wavelengths we can see, hence why we used them. 3) Mirrors aren't indestructible.

The problem is that when you amplify the EM waves, they blue-shift and their amplitude gets larger. This means more energy per photon. Because mirrors absorb part of the energy, and don't reflect all wavelengths equally, there comes a point that either a mirror would melt from the energy it's absorbing, and/or the wavelength is shifted to a point where they no longer reflect off the mirror surface. The mirror container would either melt long before the bomb goes off, or fail to cause any more reflection.

Blackhole's are still a sphere after the star collapses. And all rotate; smaller holes rotate at a higher speed, while super massive holes rotate slower. Most of the "facts" we "know" about blackholes are utter bullshit though.
We have not technically come across one, it is merely something we assumed is because of a few faint evidences of something being there.
No, black holes are definitely not 1/2 dimensional. No, they are definitely not infinitely dense. And most of all, you are definitely not getting "sucked" into it, gravity doesn't exactly work that way.
The only actual fact we can, and should say is, we have absolutely no fucking idea if, or what they are.
Objectively speaking, mathematics and all other sciences used to provide info on such things are completely made up by us. While for us, the systems are unfathomably valuable and real, they are not universally "real", so to speak. You can not universally declare something a fact. It's not how that works.
The biggest problem with all this crap is that we are arguing about obscenely vague informations we are guaranteed not to need any time in our lifetime like we are experts on the subject, and completely divert focus from things that actually matter for us.

i have questions for greater minds than mine.

1. if a ringularity exists, even on a theoretical level if we know it has to exist, then doesnt that prove we could create or find a naturally occurring a tesseract? its the other end of the spectrum just?

2. if the ergo sphere is sort of an alteration of the laws of space time, a distortion, i get that but regardless
then wouldnt anything with mass entering it according to the Mass–energy equivalence instantly jump up in mass based on the increase in speed? even with distorted rules anything with mass seeks out more mass, in this case the gravitational pull of the hole itself regardless of the increase in speed the proportional increase in mass would either lock you in an orbit till you ran out of fuel, or just suck you in?

3. if we fired electromagnetic waves at a blackhole bomb, wouldnt it just explode?
electromagnet waves don't have mass sure but they do have energy and momentum so the instant any waves escape the ergo spheres influence wouldn't they attempt to burn off that extra momentum to return to c? outputting a constant stream of energy yes, but thats not a contained reaction nor is it in anyway predictable, as photons are attempting to slow wouldn't they be being hit by photons behind them? moving only marginally faster, them being hit by the photons behind? causing a chain reaction of momentum being halted and a mounting of energy requiring an escape?

in one scenario "Boom" and in another far more terrifying scenario.
If the chain reaction backtracked inside the ergo sphere it could theoretically act as total kinetic energy sink,
the hole now has to correct and realign an unimaginable amount of photons all similarly attempting to slow in momentum as they collide, pulling the holes kinetic energy away, its a zero sum game?

im no scientist but i would love for someone to answer these thoughts for me

You are forgetting about Einstein. Time dilation becomes so extreme at the even horizon that it comes to a stop from our perspective. The black hole is, in deed spinning quite fast, from it's own perspective, but what the black hole call "1 second" is more or less forever to us, sitting outside the black hole.
All of the matter and energy that has fallen into the black hole is still at the event horizon, because no time has passed at the event horizon, since it formed.
The black hole encompasses a spherical region of space, but there is nothing (not even space) inside that region.
If we were to fly into the black hole, our friends watching from the outside would see us fade away as we head through the even horizon.
What we would see would be the even horizon getting closer and closer, then, just before we reach it it would vanish in a bright flare of Hawking radiation.
Assuming our ship can withstand this (and nothing can) we could survive, but we will have spent the rest of the time that black hole existed falling into it. This is why we never actually reached the event horizon, because the black hole evaporated before we reached the event horizon.
If we survive, we will be in real trouble. Our bodies, and our ship will comprise all of the matter in the known universe. No planets, no starts, no anything anywhere.
Our speed will be impossible to find, because there will be no other anything to compare our speed to.

''super massive black hole''

Problem. Mirrors don't reflect 100% of all the light available.
And the 'boost' the light gets is at cost of the black hole itself.
Combine that with Hawking Radiation and tadah, you've got tons of wasted material and a dying black hole.
If the waves were to move at light speed, there'd be NO WAY you could close it off without everything escaping.
The mirror piece would also already be sucked in, damaging surrounding other mirror pieces because of the black hole's gravity.
Matter cannot be created nor destroyed. Both the black hole and the waves cannot benefit from themselves, the energy within these mirrors will always stay the same.

To put it short:
You'd waste light, mirrors just to surround a black hole.

Unfortunately I think I have found a flaw in this idea... You do not get more photons when you accelerate them using the ergosphere, you get blue shifted higher energy radiation. So if you put in visible light you might get out ultraviolet x-rays or gamma rays. Unless you found a method of supplying low energy radiation like radio waves or microwaves that takes less energy than the visible light you would get out, you might not be able to use the radiation output. Furthermore a lot of high-energy radiation would eventually degrade the mirrors and damage them to the point where they would need to be replaced ... but I'm sure any future civilization that was capable of constructing this New York age would be able to figure out how to repair it and hopefully how to supply it with enough radio waves to get out usable light.

In my mind, the black hole is the tensest point in existence, and just like with a tense guitar string it takes a small amount of energy to make it work, except in this case it literally stretches space/time to the point that one “strum” of the cord will have infinite efficiency and in the process, never lose said energy, no matter how much we take.

Their not trapped 'forever'. Black holes eventually disperse the mass and energy they took over the span of their existence, it just take's a very long time. Black holes have an epicenter of mass, that builds up over time the sheer gravity force of the epicenter pulls forward anything the draws near and absorbs it into the center, black holes don't lead anywhere, their just the result of a collapsing super cell, all planets and stars have gravity, and a black hole is like a concentrated blast of that gravity over an extremely long time, but eventually the energy dissipates and releases it back into the universe. I used to think that they existed forever and that worried me, but thankfully before mr hawkings passed he was able to prove that they in fact don't last forever, what's also surprising is that technically, even if a spacecraft got too close to a black hole, it's entirely possible that the people aboard the ship could infact live out their entire lives just rotating around the rim, because apparently most black holes take several hundred years to send debris from the rim to the center. Couple other facts, there are several 100 billion planets and stars in the milky way galaxy (our galaxy) and there are about 100 million black holes, which means that roughly 0.002-0.003% of our galaxy's planets and stars have died, meaning were fairly new even though our planet is roughly 4.5 billion years old, this goes beyond the black hole concept here, but if we take into consideration the age of our galaxy and our planet and the known galaxies outside of our own, there is a higher chance for more developed alien life, just saying. Back to topic. at the very centre of the milky way there is a black hole dubbed 'Sagittarius A', it will take several quadrillion years to disperse. The smaller the black hole the shorter it's life span. On the plus side earth is safe, at least for roughly 1600 light years. Also we can't actually see black holes but we can see their rims and detect their gravity anomaly. Really puts things into perspective, i like the theory that with some very advanced technology (advanced compared to ours) that aliens might be able to harness and thus shorten the lifespan of black holes. But i'm more concerend with the fact that there is most likely just a huge empty void of space from the center of the big bang now, possibly followed by an outer shell filled with clusters of black holes, expanding outward's to the oldest dying planets and stars in the universe, it just means that eventually the milky way will become a field of black holes and emptiness too. They say space is infinite so really what were looking at is a race to stay within the recently created expanse of space. But who really knows, we don't have any scientific evidence of the event's that happen after a black hole dissolves, do they have miniature big bangs with huge releases of energy and mass that can create stars and super cells and planets all over again? If so, space is just like the immortal jellyfish infinitely dying and regenerating all over again.

I don't doubt the science behind black holes. All of this stuff about space is super interesting. But it's still **scientific theory**. We've yet to reach close to the center of our universe, and we've yet to have anything encounter black holes outside of just sorta noticing that they exist. Sure the fact that they rotate makes total sense, but to say there's one at the center of the Milky Way can't really be considered fact because we've yet to see it (or at least get readings that there's one there). It's a strong theory, definitely, but who knows if it's actually fact? Maybe there's more to it then I know.

Interesting ideas, but unfortunately the video contains some of the usual misconceptions about black holes.
There is no "inside" of a black hole; it ends at the event horizon. Therefore there is no singularity in its center. It has no center. At the horizon time comes to a standstill. Therefore nothing will ever pass through its horizon. It takes an infinite amount of time for matter even to reach the horizon. Any radiation going into a black hole will just get infinitely red-shifted, but never completely disappear.

After thinking about this over a few nights, I doubt a black hole bomb is feasible from an engineering perspective, and long-term power extraction is also problematic: 1. Assuming the super-radiant increase is effectively lossless, at some point the radiation pressure inside the mirrors will be hot enough to cause the inside surfaces of the mirrors to ablate away, causing the joints between the mirrors to fail from the reaction force, and a fizzle would occur. You'd end up with local nuclear bomb-scale explosions at the joints, and not a supernova-scale failure of the entire mirror at once. 2. This ablation reaction force would also limit the useful life of the mirrors. 3. The backside of the mirrors would radiate like a black body. A mirror completely enclosing a black hole wouldn't be necessary due to this black body radiation.

I think the mirror-based black hole bomb is pretty obviously wrong. Mirrors aren't magical things that can reflect radiation of any wavelength and with no losses.

(1) Once the radiation builds up to a high enough frequency (i.e. xrays and higher) it will simply pass through the mirrors.

(2) Even radiation that is of the correct wavelength to be reflected will experience some losses and cause thermal excitation. The mirrors will get hotter, releasing their own thermal radiation, which will also be intensified. The whole thing will get extremely hot and degrade. If nothing else happens, the radiation pressure will push outwards on the plasma that used to be mirrors and break it up until it relieves enough pressure to become stable.

In there it's mentioned how the goal of a certain organization was to actually get a naked singularity. This gets into the whole "closed time-like curves" and time-travel thing. I wonder if the ergosphere is sufficient for this effect? Presumably not. It would depend on how warped the local spacetime is.
As I understand it, basically travelling through sufficiently warped spacetime causes you to move through more space then you could have typically. That means you also moved through less time than typical. Repeat this effect and eventually you can arrive before you even left.
Another way I've thought of it involves angular momentum. Typically any spin requires 360 degrees of rotation. If one goes through sufficiently warped spacetime, I might be possible to complete a "spin" with less than 360 degrees. Meaning you complete it before you should have.

The core of a black hole cannot be a singularity because angular momentum is conserved.  If it were a single point, then it would have to spin at the speed of light in order to conserve its angular momentum.  Since black holes cannot spin at the speed of light, then they cannot be singularities.  Maybe really small, but not single points in space.

The Bible says in the last days there will be: wars and rumors of war; a one world economic/governmental/religious system; Kingdoms against kingdoms and the seas and people raging; Violence and perversion on a grand scale; Earthquakes in diverse places, etc.

... Sounds exactly like our world today, doesn't it? If that weren't enough to chew on, consider this: The Books of John and Acts combined total up to over 120+ historically verified facts. When you consider that, it gets a little difficult to write the Bible off as fairy tales when history and archaeology are on its side...

Are you paying attention yet? God is screaming at us! He warned us thousands of years in advance that all of what you are seeing would happen- and it is! It's all coming together to the letter! In fact, if you doubt the validity of Bible Prophecy, I encourage you to consider this: the Bible warns that in the last days that Damascus will become "a ruinous heap." It will become a no man's land inhabited by no one. Use that as a litmus test of sorts. Keep an eye on Damascus. If it never falls then feel free to throw out the Bible. But when Damascus does fall in the not too distant future... You'll see God is no liar. God also declares that the only way to heaven is to accept Jesus as your Savior. Good deeds won't get you there nor do good deeds erase a bad deed. If you murder somebody, that person is still dead even if you do nothing but good deeds after murdering them. You need a Savior who will forgive you of that murder because you can't save yourself.

Yet, many people will still discount God and His goodness even when shown evidence that the Bible is valid and coming true. A lot of people have difficulty believing in God because of all the evils in the world. However, this discounting of the only Person who can save you may be less of an inborn frustration or complaint and more of a hidden longing, placed there by the very One who planted His own image into the body and soul of every person He created. Where does this deep-seated intuition that suffering and pain are not right come from if we're just amalgamations of atoms, as the atheists say…?

What if, perhaps, this intuition points to something deeper? Something built into ourselves that reflects our true nature and identity? What if this revulsion against suffering and pain is a reminder of paradise, on one hand, and an anticipation of New Jerusalem on the other?

Perhaps it's the cry of the human spirit for God. For our Creator. The only One who can, and will, fix this mess.

As I've said, time is short. Bible Prophecy is happening at a frightening pace. You could argue, "You're just being paranoid like all the other fundamentalists. Haven't we always had these types of problems?" Sure... But never at this magnitude or frequency! Check the news for yourselves. The amount of earthquakes, bloodshed, madness and horrific weather events are off the charts! Don't be deceived into thinking it's not as bad as it seems out there. The devil wants you to stay anemic and apathetic. Don't let that jerk deceive you. Or win your soul. Satan wants nothing more than for you to roll your eyes, scoff under your breath and put this whole "God" business under the rug. He wants you to continue believing that Hell and God and the afterlife is nonsense. That the Bible is all fairy tale nonsense of Jesus riding dinosaurs; that it's stuff only the weak-minded, brainwashed people believe. He'll gladly coax your pride, making you believe you're far too "reasoned" to believe in such things. However, Satan believes the Bible. Every jot and word of it. He doesn't see it as fairy-tale nonsense since it details his coming destruction. He just doesn't want YOU to believe it so he can drag your soul down with him when it's time for him to go!

Don't let him drag you down into the grave with him. Don't be played! Hell is a very real place-- a place of eternal separation, loneliness, and despair. No friends, no family... just you. A-L-O-N-E. In the dark. Miserable for all eternity. If hell wasn't real, what on earth was Jesus willing to die for to protect us from...? Bill Nye thinks hell won't be so bad; he claims he's willing to hold onto his darwinian beliefs even if it means he's hellbound for it. I hope you won't share in that kind of disillusioned thinking...

Before you're sent to hell, you'll appear at the Great White Throne Judgment. Whether you believe in hell or not makes no difference--that giant throne you want to avoid seeing at all costs will be your destiny if Christ isn't your Savior. At the Great White Throne Judgment the books are thrown wide open and the past is recalled. Details and sins long forgotten or covered up are brought to light. Plenty of people will have a list of good deeds: acts of charity, love, and sacrifice. All their good deeds will be carefully considered... but none of them will be good enough to gain them admittance into heaven. The good deeds they did will have an impact on where they end up in the lake of fire, however. Hell will not be the same for everyone, but it will still be eternal misery... misery you could have easily avoided.

Sinners will wish they had done just a little less evil so their punishment could be a little more tolerable. Pornographers will wish they hadn't made so many videos. Control freaks will wish they hadn't been so angry and abusive. The internet troll will wish he hadn't cursed and slung so many demeaning insults toward a stranger online. And the abortionist will wish they hadn't killed any pre-born infants. All sins will be exposed. There's no way out... unless...

Unless you accept Christ as your Savior. Confess that you're a sinner, repent of your sins and accept His free gift of salvation and grace. It's all yours... free for the taking! Jesus is the only way to get out of what's coming soon upon this world. I know you've probably heard "Jesus loves you" a million times in your life, and it probably sounds like an empty mantra by now... but it really is the truth! Do you know why you exist? Have you ever stopped and pondered about that...? Nothing in this life comes to be without God's approval first. That means that God thought  you were so worth the effort that He created you!

Or maybe you're wondering, "How do I know that only Jesus can save me? What about Islam? Or what about Hinduism or Buddhism? How do I know that the Bible isn't a book of fiction and myths? In fact, what about all the starving kids in Africa? If God is so "just and loving," explain that one!" These are incredibly valid questions that deserve real answers. In fact, how can you even know God is real to begin with?

If you have deep questions related to God, or if you're just remotely curious about Him... I encourage you to search out these authors. I'll even list some of their books that address just about any issue or question you could have about God:

Frank Turek- "Stealing From God: Why Atheists Need God to Make Their Case"

Andreas Kostenberger- "Truth Matters"

Louis Markos- "Apologetics for the 21st Century"

Norman L. Geisler- "When Skeptics Ask," "I Don't Have Enough Faith To Be An Atheist"

C.S. Lewis- "Mere Christianity"

Lee Strobel- "The Case For Christ," "The Case For A Creator," "The Case For Grace"

Ravi Zacharias- "The End of Reason," "Jesus Among Other Gods," "Can Man Live Without God?" "Why Suffering?"

Philip Yancey- "Reaching For The Invisible God," "Disappointment With God"

Also, the "One Minute Apologist" right here on YouTube offers quick videos that tackle tough questions about God.

**

Why am I telling you all this? Especially when this has absolutely nothing to do with the video you're watching? Simple: to warn you. To offer you a life line. Deep down, if you have discernment and common sense, you can tell something is dreadfully wrong with this world and something in your heart is telling you to get right with God before it's too late. Don't ignore that voice! Listen to it, no matter how small it is. I'm just a beggar telling other beggars where they can go to find the Bread of Life.

Don't let anything stop you from finding God. To quote Erwin Lutzer: "Standing at the Great White Throne Judgment will be hordes from every country of the world, from every religion in the world, with the best intentions in the world. They will learn too late that God is serious about justice, and if Christ does not bear their punishment, they must bear their own."

Don't lose your life! Let Christ save you while there's still time.

I had no clue about this, but predicted that the singularity must be a circle (or hollow sphere), because there simply wouldnt have been enough TIME for any significant amount of matter to have fallen in and reached the absolute center. Because time dilation means that as you get ever closer to the exact center of gravity, it takes longer and longer to reach.

Basically, there must be a shell of matter around the middle, which in turn becomes more and more dense as more and more incoming matter "bunches up" there due to time dilation and friction with already existing matter in there (think, a dense neutron shell). The closer you get, the slower you move, but the more matter already is bunched up in "traffic jam".
For the singularity to be a point, the universe must have existed for trillions of years for the matter to have had enough time to sink into the absolute center, or arguably would even need Infinite time, if we propose that the gravity at a singularity is indeed infinite, thus NO black hole singularity can ever have anything in the perfect center, because it'd take infinite time to reach the center due to time dilation.

Thus all singularities must be circles or hollow shells, they simply cannot be "points".
Really interesting thought experiment. Never before seen any science video on youtube mention this concept.
Props to Kurzgesagt.

Also this brings up the question, if the surface of a black hole, the actual "hard" physical surface, spins at speeds approaching luminal speeds, what happens to matter that falls in? We've only thought about matter falling in as simply stretching into infinity and never being seen again, but would it not make more sense that if ANYTHING hits such an insanely rapidly spinning surface, the matter falling in would simply be obliterated into energy?
Partly via the gravity, partly via the insane speed collision of the spinning surface.
Wouldn't basically any atom falling in be colliding with the atoms of the surface, in a fusion explosion (or fission, if they probably cant stay together long enough)? I mean, there's no way any substance can survive that trek through the spinning mass without being ripped apart into bare electrons, protons and neutrons, right? Perhaps even ripped into their quark constituants.

Black holes have been sensationalized by main stream science and the media. IMHO, they are nothing but a vacuum left behind by an supernova. I think of it this way... when a bomb explodes there there is an exothermic reaction that generates enough energy pushing all existing matter within outward from the center point of the explosion thus resulting in a vacuum in and around the center. Immediately after which air moves back in filling the void/vacuum. Same thing with a super nova. Since space (the universe) is a field (in my opinion dark matter is a construct of main stream scientists who believe everything is an atom... or... atomism) and nothing more, it takes the vacuum/void generated by the supernova (explosion) many, many eons to become filled with 'matter' (not dark matter.... no such thing) from outside sources (other parts of orbiting matter, asteroids, gases etc.). A field is something like gravity, a magnetic attraction, or electricity. Remember, scientists still don't know what gravity or electricity is. But in my opinion they are fields and don't consists of atoms. Just my thinking lol...

You're mistaken conceptually. It wouldn't merely make the light echoing around inside the chamber BRIGHTER, continually replenishing itself as energy is drawn off or gaining in strength exponentially, it would increase its energy by raising its frequency, and that means the number of photons doesn't increase. Which would mean that the light would simply be blueshifted until it no longer reflected off the mirrors and penetrated through it as gamma rays or heat the mirror up to the point where it physically failed which would be way before "supernova" levels. It just wouldn't work, either as a bomb or a very good energy source. At best, the energy you could draw from it would be the heat of the material of your dyson sphere being heated by the radiation to being white hot, and then it would be like a not particularly bright star, and that's IF you could build a dyson sphere around a black hole that holds together even without the strain due to the radiation heating from the inside, which you can't.

Scientists keep using the "Singularity" theory and having to change it ever so slightly to keep it working. I'm having serious doubts that a blackhole is a 0-dimension object.

My guess is that it just pushes matter to the limit of it's spacial properties and makes them as small as possible. Gases seem to overlap at this point, so I can understand why they might think it's a point with no volume.

But even at the core of this idea, doesn't 1 atom have volume? If not, then maybe it is 0-dimension. If so, then the smallest a blackhole could be is the size of 1 atom, which I still have trouble believing. Even with the gravitational force of a blackhole, the sheer amount of atoms forced into a tiny space should still be strong enough to push themselves away from each other, even if it's by a teeny tiny amount.

An interesting theory but I believe it's flawed. First: the assumption that the energy / light could actually escape instead of being fully consumed. But the main problem is that even if some energy could escape then there will be no way to predict how that is going to happen. After all: the laws of physics mostly no longer apply. So how are you going to make sure that the energy always gets reflected back at the right angles? You can't. Not if the angle of the incoming energy beam would be completely random. You could even end up with the energy beam getting reflected straight into the black hole. Which would be the end of the story.

Ok, maybe this is wishfull thinking and me refusing to accept that existence must end, but I once read an article by Isaac Asimov in which he talked about what would happen after maximum entropy is reached. The second law is probabilistic, meaning not that a drop in entropy is impossible but that it's so unlikely it's practically impossible. But after max entropy is reached, things will stay like that forever, that's a very long time, enough for the most unlikely things to happen, from a tiny drop in entropy to a massive one.
I think it makes sense, but I will change my mind if someone explains that there's something wrong in this reasoning.

This particular video, due to its subject matter, should come with a huge asterisk. This is all based on untested theories. We still have not even been able to observe a black hole, because we can't bounce light off of them. And we have never interacted with one because we are still stuck on this rock. And the problem with this video is that you are stating these things as fact, and you just can't do that when talking about black holes, because we have literally zero facts about black holes. About the only thing we CAN say for certain about black holes is that they truly exist, as evidenced by all the things around them behaving certain ways.

Note: I am very pleased by the overwhelming majority of the information here and the way you explain it. But this one, not so much.

Super nerdy comment incoming! There is another possible option for using black holes to make power! So: enter Kugelblitzes. As most sufficiently nerdy people will tell you, Kugelblitzes are special black holes made, paradoxically, out of light. Black holes are really, really, really, stupidly, infinitely dense bunches of mass. But mass, by e=mc^2, and some other Einstein maths that no-one ever talks about, probably, because it requires finding the special symbols on your keyboard and no-one has time for that, is just "frozen energy" as Niel Degrasse Tyson once put it. So, if you eat, say, Mercury and all of its delicious iron core and oxygen crust you can make enough reflective hematite to power huge mazers/lazers and focus +/- 10% of the Sun's output onto about an atometer, then you can feed mass into and harvest the hawking radiation from that tiny black hole. AND you got yourself a 40% efficient mass to energy converter. Provided the Kugelblitz doesn't over-radiate and explode, break containment and eat the facility, fail to form and explode instead or eats a nearby planet.

My hypothesis:
Maybe that's why black holes have polar jets: to keep from blowing up (I know; I'm anthropomorphizing). Perhaps in a black hole Dyson sphere we need to have "jet vents" to prevent the explosion.

In a way, evolution works for the universe, too. We don't see black holes that exist without jets, and so any that are out there without jets would be either diminishing or will have blown up. So we see black holes with jets because that is the most stable configuration, and thus these are the longest lived black holes.

First of all we know that the most massive thing in our solar system (hint hint) is Sol, or the sun to put it in terms people use everyday. This gives off more than enough energy to power whatever the hell is happening on our entire pebble of a planet, yet we are nowhere near being able to capture it any more than needed to send a few students in homemade cars across Australia. But let's forget about the sun, and all that gravity keeping the solar system together, and let's just focus our attention on a black hole. Regarding the death of the universe. "That is not dead which can eternal lie, and with strange aeons even death may die".

Random processes can eventually recreate orderly conditions hospitable to life, so the universe won't end up dead forever. On the other hand, these little random occurrences are so small compared to the long stretches of entropic nothingness that they're basically unnoticeable. On the other other hand, nobody's conscious during the heat death stages, so there's nobody to perceive how big they are, they'll only notice the randomly orderly stages.

I don't know about the other part but I think the blackhole bomb is impossible. If the type of blackhole bomb as explained in the video can explode with an energy as high as a supernova, it would mean that the mirror first has to be able to contain that enormous amount of energy without melting away.

It's like a balloon. You can blow a balloon up however large you want but the bursting of that balloon can only be as energetic as the balloon's material in holding that potential energy. Likewise, the material that the mirror is made of is not perfect and will absorb some of the photon's energy. The mirror will melt away (like a balloon blowing up at it's weakest part) and the energy buildup will never reach supernova level. If we can't even build a mirror around our sun without the corona melting it off, I doubt we can do that to a blackhole to contain a supernova's worth of energy.

PS: Even the wall (the analogy used in the video) can really only withstand as many high speed balls in so far its cement could hold the bricks together.

Here's a slight problem, the ergo sphere is about 1.5 Rs for a non-rotating black hole, similar values for a rotating one just not symmetrical. Now go ahead and calculate the tidal acceleration acting on your 10cm thick mirror/sphere, you're going to get over 30 million g-forces acting on it for a 1 solar mass black hole.

Not to mention what others have already commented on with what kind of meta-material that can reflect the entirety of the electromagnetic spectrum. What you'll most likely find is that as the energy builds up it won't get reflected as much as absorbed , which the IR radiation from the heat would help keep this whole "black hole bomb" going, but you'll leak 50% (the side of the mirror facing out) and the maximum energy gain from the Penrose process is only 20% means you'll end up losing more energy than you gain. That is unless you build a Dyson sphere around your "black hole bomb" in which case you would need to convert the IR radiation into usable power

I love videos like this because this is the kind of stuff I'm passionate about. Space n' all that gubbins. I knew about ring black holes, but I didn't know about these ways to exploit them! Interesting stuff.

The part where time is fluctuated in the ergosphere is most interesting bit since it poses the question of the relationship between gravity and time. The range effect of time as a byproduct exerted by gravity itself. Assuming, that variant time oscillation is dependent on relative gravitational densities suggests that there must be different temporal subspaces in our universe.

Our milky galaxy has myriads of solar and planetary systems intertwined in that spiral dance and balance the gravitational effects of each other to give us that uniform time space experience. Or possibly more relative to own solar system. Who knows.

Thus, hypothetically if there is no gravitational effect then there should not be any temporal space. Such a non temporal subspace will mean that we have reached the border limit of our temporal universe. The ever expanding universe is probably due to the conversion of non temporal subspace to temporal one where light energises and sets motion to this universal process unless the light source is extinguished or hindered by orbiting mass planetary bodies.

So this idea of encasing the black hole might be workable only if we can make better simulations of black holes and understand which of which is more humanly manageable and effective. Nice one!

Honestly, if you want to harvest energy WAY into the dark age of the universe (like 10^60 years), stick to Hawking radiation.
Also, way into the dark age, the landau limit (the minimum energy needed to flip a bit, as a function of the averageinimum temperature of your environment) goes into overdrive because it's so cold. So you can run a simulation of humans...as long as you slow down their subjective time a few billion times since energy from Hawking radiation comes on pretty slowly. They'll experience 10^50 years of simulated reality, basically an eternity. If anything this period would objectively be the most significant for civilization of all time. Even the biggest galaxy spanning civilizations of old will be irrelevant in age and number compared to these minds orbiting a black hole.

A few questions to which I'm sure there are answers:
1. If black holes are spinning, does it have momentum? How is its intertia distributed on the "ringularity"? Would it expand if it spins faster?
2. If we construct an infinitely strong ball around a black hole, would it be in equilibrium, since the black hole's gravitational pull propagates sphierically and is exerted equally on the inner surface of the sphere? If one side of the sphere is pulled towards the singularity, wouldn't this mean the black hole is also pushing against the opposite side of the sphere?
3. If black holes have infinite density, I understand that the singularity can, effectively, hold an infinite quantity of matter and never become "full"; thus, if an object is moving towards a black hole, wouldn't this mean the black hole is doing work to the object, and that energy can be harvested in some way? I apologize if this is substantially the same as the one presented in the video.
4. If black holes consume objects which exhibit magnetism, would the black hole retain this characteristic? According to Newton, would this mean we can repel a black hole magnetically if we can detect its polarity?
5. If we throw an amount of antimatter equal to the mass of a black hole into it, would this annihilate the singularity?

Electromagnetic waves pick up energy by getting shorter in wavelength.
